February 7, 1982: Fiction
AN INDECENT OBSESSION, by Colleen McCullough. (Harper & Row, $13.50.) A
nurse and her charges in a special-care ward of a World War II hospital.
THE HOTEL NEW HAMPSHIRE, by John Irving. (Dutton/Henry Robbins, $15.50.)
Life with an eccentric family.
SPRING MOON, by Bette Bao Lord. (Harper & Row, $14.95.) Tradition and
revolution in modern China seen through the life of an upper-class family.
MARCO POLO, IF YOU CAN, by William F. Buckley Jr. (Doubleday, $13.95.)
Blackford Oakes's quest for a mole in the C.I.A. takes him to Russia.
NOBLE HOUSE, by James Clavell. (Delacorte, $19.95.) A British-Chinese
struggle for control of one of Hong Kong's oldest trading houses.
THE DEAN'S DECEMBER, by Saul Bellow. (Harper & Row, $13.95.) During a
deathbed vigil in Rumania, a college dean from Chicago realizes some truths
about his own land.
CUJO, by Stephen King. (Viking, $13.95.) Monsters haunt a New York family
seeking peace in rural Maine.
NO TIME FOR TEARS, by Cynthia Freeman. (Arbor House, $14.95.) A dauntless
woman leads her family from Czarist Russia to Palestine to New York's diamond
center.
MASQUERADE, by Kit Williams. (Schocken Books, $10.95.) An illustrated fable
about the sun, the moon and a hidden treasure.
RABBIT IS RICH, by John Updike. (Knopf, $13.95.) Harry Angstrom of ''Rabbit,
Run'' returns in the chips but unfulfilled.
REMEMBRANCE, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $14.95.) An Italian princess, in
quest of romance, finds frustration, then fulfillment in America.
NORTH AND SOUTH, by John Jakes. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $14.95.) The
friendship of two wealthy families - one in Pennsylvania, the other in Carolina - is
strained by the Civil War.
GORKY PARK, by Martin Cruz Smith. (Random House, $13.95.) A triple murder in
Moscow leads to a chase on two continents.
RED DRAGON, by Thomas Harris. (Putnam's, $13.95.) An ex-F.B.I. man on the
trail of a psychopathic killer.
A GREEN DESIRE, by Anton Myrer. (Putnam's, $14.95.) A woman caught
between the clashing ambitions of two brothers during the springtime of this
February 7, 1982
Non-Fiction
A LIGHT IN THE ATTIC, by Shel Silverstein. (Harper & Row, $10.95.) Humor in
cartoons and verse.
A FEW MINUTES WITH ANDY ROONEY, by Andrew A. Rooney. (Atheneum,
$12.95.) Reflections on contemporary life by the television commentator.
PATHFINDERS, by Gail Sheehy. (Morrow, $15.95.) How ordinary people cope
with the normal crises of life.
JANE FONDA'S WORKOUT BOOK, by Jane Fonda. (Simon & Schuster, $15.95.)
An exercise book for women, seasoned with the film star's philosophy of physical
well-being.
THE LORD GOD MADE THEM ALL, by James Herriot. (St. Martin's, $13.95.) The
further adventures of the Yorkshire vet at home and behind the Iron Curtain.
LAID BACK IN WASHINGTON, by Art Buchwald. (Putnam's, $12.95.) The
columnist has his funny say on politics, sex and life in general.
THE WALK WEST: A Walk Across America 2, by Peter and Barbara Jenkins.
(Morrow, $14.95.) A newlywed couple's adventures on a trek from Louisiana to
Oregon.
AT DAWN WE SLEPT, by Gordon W. Prange. (McGraw-Hill, $22.95.) A revisionist
history o f the events culminating in the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor.
NEVER-SAY-DIET BOOK, by Richard Simmons. (Warner, $14.95.) A regimen for
exercise, diet and life style devised by a Hollywood television personality.
COSMOS, by Carl Sagan. (Random House, $22.95.) Thirteen billion years of the
universe's evolution explained by the NASA medal-winning space scientist.
THE CINDERELLA COMPLEX, by Colette Dowling. (Summit Books, $12.95.)
From her own experience, a writer argues that women have a hidden fear of
independence.
HOW TO MAKE LOVE TO A MAN, by Alexandra Penney. (Clarkson N. Potter,
$10.) How-to.
ELVIS, by Albert Goldman. (McGraw-Hill, $14.95.) The life and death of Elvis
Presley.
FROM BAUHAUS TO OUR HOUSE, by Tom Wolfe. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux,
$10.95.) A critical look at contemporary architecture.
THE BREAKS OF THE GAME, by David Halberstam. (Knopf, $15.) The world of
professional basketball.
